content: searching for king sexred by lorraine rayson this design was inspired by the wonderful british comedy television series detectorists based on the day-to-day lives of two friends andy and lance and their love of metal detecting which weaves a story of mostly joy friendship and humour with a few hiccups along the way andy and lance s dream is to find the burial place of king sexred of the east saxons thus the name of the pattern the scenes in the series are stunning as is the music and imagery 1 ben dowell of the times described the show as being steeped in a gentle kindness and sam wollaston of the guardian says a beautifully written and performed slice of life 1 these stranded colour work socks are worked toe up with a heel flap and gusset the socks are slightly potato chippy just one more celtic motif sizes adult small medium large s-64 m-72 l-80 sts finished circumference approximate 18 20 5 23 cm/7 8 9 inches yarn fingering weight sock yarn in 2 colours with good contrast allow 70-80 g for mc and 50-60 g for cc a solid or tonal would work well for mc gauge measured after washing and laying flat to dry 36 sts/40 rounds = 10 cm/4 inches over stranded colour work needles for working small circumference in the round 2 25 mm/us1 needles or size required to achieve gauge notions stitch markers bor marker 3 side stripe markers ssm1 ssm2 ssm3 2 gusset markers gm1 gm2 and 1 removable marker plus your normal collection of notions 1 https //en wikipedia org/wiki/detectorists this pattern is for personal use only ©lorraine rayson 2024 s-64 m-72 l-80 searching for king sexred-toe up-v01-230824 page 1 / 27 notes sizing information choose a size to give you approximately 10% negative ease in circumference measure foot circumference and multiple by 0 9 i knit non-stranded colour work socks on 2 25 mm/us1 needles with 60-64 sts and for stranded colour work socks i use the same needle size but with 70-72 sts pattern notes the pattern is written using stitch markers to separate sections of the sock therefore the pattern can be easily adapted for use with any configuration of needles slip markers as required the first half of the round is the front of the sock the second half of the round is the back of the sock the ɸ symbol is used within the pattern to indicate that further information is available in the techniques and resources sections below measurements are rounded to the closest full or half cm / full or quarter inch read the pattern through before starting construction information the socks have a 4 stitch stripe on each side between the sole and instep and later between the front and back of the leg a 6 stitch stripe is worked in the centre of the sole and this stripe eventually becomes part of the gusset the needle and marker
